title: Debenhams chief to stand down next year
text:
Debenhams chief to stand down next year Debenhams chief to stand down next year DEBENHAMS is looking for a new chief executive after Michael Sharp said he will step down next year following fi e years at the helm of the department store group. PUBLISHED: 19:48, Thu, Oct 22, 2015 | UPDATED: 20:02, Thu, Oct 22, 2015 GETTY Debehams is looking for a new chief executive 
Sharp, 58, who has worked for Debenhams or its predecessor, the Burton Group, for 30 years and took the top job in 2011, said he had always intended to serve a five-year term. 
He played down suggestions his departure may be linked to reported concerns among some investors about the company’s performance, as its annual results and outlook showed his turnaround strategy is starting to bear fruit. 
Pre-tax profit rose 7.3 per cent to £113.5million and the group enjoyed its strongest ever brand launch with Nine by Savannah Miller in 65 stores for the autumn. 
Online sales grew 11.4 per cent, with 40 per cent being generated from mobiles. Debenhams Michael Sharp says he always intended to stay for just five years I believe Debenhams is capable of competing in the ever changing and challenging world of multi-channel retailing. Michael Sharp 
Sharp, is steering Debenhams away from promotions, while working to improve online delivery options and expand its international presence as well as signing concession deals Costa Coffee and Sports Direct to fill store space. 
He said: “We have had an encouraging start to the year, with strong new product launches which have been well received by customers and we are in good shape to build on last year’s strong performance over peak trading. 
“We are increasingly confident in the direction of the business and as a result we will accelerate our new initiatives, such as the roll-out of our successful space optimisation trials and new international growth opportunities.” 
Sharp will continue to lead the business during the key festive trading period and help the board identify his successor from internal and external candidates. Debenhams Sharp leaves Debenhams in a position of strength 
Trading director Suzanne Harlow is seen as the leading internal candidate. 
Sharp said: “I believe Debenhams is capable of competing in the ever changing and challenging world of multi-channel retailing. I accepted the job of chief with the intention of spending five years in the role and now is the right time for the board to begin the process of identifying my successor. 
“I hope being transparent about my intentions will stop recent speculation becoming a distraction, allowing us to focus on delivering our strategy and the important Christmas trading period.” 
Debenhams’ chairman Nigel Northridge said Sharp would leave the firm “in a strong position to compete and deliver long-term sustainable growth”. 
James Collins, retail analyst at broker Stifel, said: “Sharp’s intention to resign is from a position of strength, with the business delivering on its priorities.” 
Shares rose 2¾p to 83¾p. Related articles
